title: 112_s3531
content: Expansion of credit for hydrogen-related alternative fuel vehicle refueling property. Expansion of credit for hydrogen-related alternative fuel vehicle refueling property, including an increase in the credit percentage to 50% for hydrogen-related property and the removal of the dollar limitation for such property. Additionally, the credit is allowable for refueling property for certain motor vehicles designed for carrying or towing loads. The amendment expands the credit for hydrogen-related alternative fuel vehicle refueling property, increasing the credit percentage to 50% and removing the dollar limitation. It now includes specified off-highway vehicles for the storage or dispensing of hydrogen fuel. The term "motor vehicle" refers to vehicles designed for carrying or towing loads, excluding certain equipment like farm tractors and vehicles operating exclusively on rails. The credit for hydrogen property has been extended through 2016. The credit for hydrogen property has been extended through December 31, 2016. The amendments made by the Act apply to property placed in service after the enactment date for taxable years ending after that date. The amendment for hydrogen refueling property applies to property placed in service after December 31, 2014. Increased investment credit for more efficient fuel cells. Increased investment credit for more efficient fuel cells, with a 50% credit for qualified fuel cell property in a combined heat and power system with an energy efficiency of 70% or more, and a 40% credit for systems with an energy efficiency of at least 60% but less than 70%. The current amendment increases the energy efficiency requirement for a 40% credit on qualified fuel cell property to at least 60% but less than 70%. Amendments are made to sections of the Code to reflect this change. The credit limit for qualified fuel cell property placed in service during the taxable year is specified based on the capacity of the property, ranging from $1,500 to $2,500 for each 0.5 kilowatt. The amendments made by this section will apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act, with a credit limit of $1,500 for each 0.5 kilowatt of qualified fuel cell property capacity.
